name: Shangri-La's Rasa Ria Resort

reviews.text: 6 of us, 2 adults, one old age pensioner and three children between 4 and 8 stayed for the last 3 weeks in February 2008, the first half at the Rasa Ria and the second at the Tanjung Aru.
reviews.title: Great for the kids - wonderful service

reviews.text: Rasa Ria
reviews.title: Didn't want to leave

likes.liked: — Great staff, great location, food excellent - everything
likes.disliked: — Unaccompanied young children in the games room, who's parent had obviously sent there so they could have a quiet evening, but this was not the hotel's fault

reviews.title: Just Wonderful!
reviews.text: We stayed at the Rasa Ria for the first 7 nights. Fantastic hotel and the service was impeccable. We only had the standard rainforest rooms but they were comfortable and suited us. Unfortunately we had a lot of bad weather so some of the activities that the kids had been looking forward to were cancelled but they still had a ball. We went to see the Orang Utans here and Sepilok and we're a little disappointed as apparently they don't like the rain anymore than we do, so the sightings were limited. Turtle Island would have been fantastic without the rain, but we still had a good experience.

reviews.text: My 8 year old did the ranger experience at the RR reserve and loved it.
reviews.title: Wonderful!

reviews.text: The kids pool was great and the slide made for hours of amusement and the beach was fab for building sandcastles and playing in the surf (no snorkelling).
reviews.title: Remote 5 star

likes.liked: — Luxury, sunsets, OrangUtans, free cooking demos

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed here at the beginning of April for 3 nights after a 2 week trip around Borneo. The Rasa Ria is situated on Tuaran beach about an hour’s drive North of the airport. It’s a beautiful setting and Tuaran is a lovely wide beach with a designated swimming area and plenty of water sports.
reviews.title: Peaceful setting

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The hotel is isolated and you rely on it’s restaurants which are expensive by Malaysian standards (expect to pay UK prices), however this was by far the best food we ate in our time in Malaysia. The breakfasts are very good with a huge choice. In the evenings we ate at the Coffee Terrace (varied menu, the steak was very good and tender), the Indian Restaurant which was very good quality and Coast which is pricey but good (there is a dress code for this restaurant though so don’t wear flip flops or you will be turned away as we discovered!).
reviews.title: Very nice but not exclusive luxury

reviews.text: The hotel has a kid’s club and seems quite geared towards family holidays. If you want to get away from noisy children in the pool area I’d recommend either booking a room at the more expensive Ocean Suite (which had a very quiet pool area) or choosing some of the many sunloungers in the gardens further away from the pool (be warned though, we noticed significant numbers or guests reserving their beds with towels from early in the morning before they went to breakfast and they weren’t all German!). As we were there during the Easter holidays I think the hotel was probably busier than normal.
reviews.title: A Long way to come but a fantastic location
Amazing
reviews.text: We found the rooms comfortable, clean and well equipped with TV, tea and coffee facilities, complimentary bottles of water, dressing gowns.
My husband played golf while we were here. The course is superb but expect to pay a lot and it was slow going.
reviews.title: Fantastic family holiday.

reviews.title: amazing place

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: This is a perfectly nice 3.5 to 4 star hotel. I'd recommend it for family vacations or reunions but not for a luxury honeymoon or romantic getaway. My husband and I booked this hotel for our anniversary and while we had a great time, I was a little disappointed as I expected more from a Shangri-La. There's no drink service by the pool - you must walk to the bar to get your drinks. The place also looks worn in places: the public bathrooms are extremely basic, the landscaping is a bit bare with lots of soggy grassy areas, the bathroom fixtures in the room were a bit loose with mineral buildup, there was also very old-fashioned looking stucco in the bathroom. I understand there's a new wing that is very nice, but that doesn't change the fact that the public areas of the hotel are still a bit worn. That said, it's a very nice family hotel with a nice pool that has two kiddie sections and a slide. The wildlife preserve next to hotel is also convenient and pretty cool. Service is friendly and the food was decent.
reviews.title: It's nice, but not luxury

reviews.text: We were there in feb on honeymoon and to be honest i am actually lost for words on how to describe just how amazing this place is. paradise on earth. staff are so unbelievably friendly and helpful. we were slightly apprehensive about the weather in feb but in two weeks it literally rained on one day for 40 mins and we stayed in the pool while it did (sure we weren't going to get any wetter!)
reviews.title: Out of this world

reviews.text: we always maintain that there are too many places in the world to go anywhere twice - but we're counting the days till we go back. GO THERE - you wont be disappointed!
reviews.title: Perfection

likes.liked: — The perfect location, and the fact that the hotel complemented its surroundings.

reviews.title: Faultless
reviews.text: Myself and my wife stayed for a week with our two children (aged 10 and 8). We found the location to be beautiful, the wildlife to be fascinating and the hotel staff to be friendly and helpful. We found it a thoroughly relaxing, luxurious experience.

description: Shangri-La's Rasa Ria Resort is set on Pantai Dalit beach surrounded by 400 acres of lush tropical vegetation, including a unique nature reserve. Here you'll meet Sabah's icon, the fascinating Orang Utan, as well as a remarkable array of indigenous flora and fauna. Unexpected encounters with hornbills who glide right overhead, peacocks walking by during breakfast, a friendly bear cat greeting you from a tree or the occasional wild rabbit, iguana or squirrel crossing your path are all part of the magic of this remarkable resort. Shangri-La's Rasa Ria Resort goes beyond the offerings of Kota Kinabalu hotels by providing numerous options for relaxation. This includes the magnificent Spa at Dalit Bay, a wide range of water sports, Rasa Ria's own catamarans for cruises and deep sea fishing, a challenging 18-hole championship golf course, ATV safaris, tennis, horse riding, a fitness centre and, of course, a fun-filled Kids' Club to care for younger visitors.
